results.title: Techniques of paper sculpture
results.brief_description: Demonstrates the basic techniques of paper sculpture - the cut, bend, fold and score - and their application in making a mask and a party favour. Shows commercial applications in window sets, art posters, and stage sets.

results.title: Techniques
results.creator_credit: Eve Cotton and Center for Humanities
results.brief_description: By analysing and comparing great paintings from different periods, this series provides a unique introduction to art. This program examines the techniques used to produce different styles of painting. The techniques examined are: fresco, tempera and oil, water colour, pastel and prints.

results.title: Technicolor
results.brief_description: The first star of a Technicolor feature film was Miriam Hopkins, who played the titular character in Becky Sharp (1935), the first feature to use the three-strip technique after its introduction in 1932.

constellations_primary.name: Over the Technicolor rainbow
constellations_primary.description: This Constellation explores the beginning and legacy of Technicolor and was created by Swinburne Cinema and Screen Studies students Adam Virgona and Kristian Vass.

results.description:
When most people think about Technicolor, they think about The Wizard of Oz (1939). As Dorothy steps out of her dreary sepia life and into Munchkinland, she’s enveloped in glorious Technicolor. That kaleidoscope of highly saturated hues is actually produced from just three colours – red, green and blue – recorded on individual film strips and then dyed. This is the three-strip Technicolor process.

But Judy Garland wasn’t the first star of a Technicolor feature film. That triumph goes to Miriam Hopkins, who played the titular character in Becky Sharp (1935), the first feature to use the three-strip technique after its introduction in 1932. Technicolor was the most popular colouring system in Hollywood until the mid-1950s, when single-strip processes were developed.
description_for_label:
When most people think about Technicolor, they think about The Wizard of Oz (1939). As Dorothy steps out of her dreary sepia life and into Munchkinland, she’s enveloped in glorious Technicolor. That kaleidoscope of highly saturated hues is actually produced from just three colours – red, green and blue – recorded on individual film strips and then dyed. This is the three-strip Technicolor process.

But Judy Garland wasn’t the first star of a Technicolor feature film. That triumph goes to Miriam Hopkins, who played the titular character in Becky Sharp (1935), the first feature to use the three-strip technique after its introduction in 1932. Technicolor was the most popular colouring system in Hollywood until the mid-1950s, when single-strip processes were developed.

results.title: Technically speaking - career futures for women
results.brief_description: Shows girls working in technical occupations. Indicates the range of jobs available, the prerequisites, work conditions, and attitudes by employers and fellow workers to girls in these jobs. Also shows how parents and teachers have discouraged girls from taking up these occupations.

results.title: Technical student
results.creator_credit: John Fletcher, Leon Clore and Basic Films
results.brief_description: Facilities for technological training in Britain today, particularly in relation to industry. The “sandwich” course typifying the cooperation being achieved between industry and education. Follows students through a four-year electronic engineering course alternating six months employment in the factory with six months study under a tutor at a technical college.

results.title: Tech Talk. Episodes 9 & 10
results.creator_credit: John Kyle, SBS-TV and Allenog Pty Ltd
results.brief_description: A compilation tape containing eight programmes designed to help young people in their career choices. There is also a segment on survival skills The topics covered are as follows:- Zookeeper and Animal technician, Australian History Industry, Permannent part-time work in the Banking industry, Fire-fighting either with the Metropolitan Fire Brigade or Country Fire Brigade, Visual display artist, Bar attendant, Surviving in a city and Buying your fist car. The program is presented by Michael Schildberger
